text:
I'm sure there's a rich and important historical context of the pardons the US president can make, but I'll never understand the concept. This is not Trump bashing, or aimed at any political party, so I hope it's not "politics". It's not even "America is stupid" either, each country has their quirks. This just seems like such a weird thing a country's leader can do
> The <http://www.cnn.com/2021/01/20/politics/lil-wayne-kodak-black-trump/index.html|rapper Lil Wayne received a pardon> after pleading guilty to a gun possession charge in Miami. Another rapper, Kodak Black, received a commutation after he pleaded guilty to a weapons charge.
:confusedpuppy:

attachments.text: The White House announced early Wednesday that President Donald Trump has granted a pardon to rapper Lil Wayne and a commutation to rapper Kodak Black, two of the raft of pardons and commutations on his final day in office.

text: Finland has that too. If I’m not mistaken, ”lifetime in prison” can only end by presidential pardon here. Sentence in years has a maximum of something like 20 years, and they don’t pile up as in the US. I believe this is roughly correct, but I’m no expert.

text: In some sense I can understand one of the types of pardon mentioned under Chile: a law is significantly changed, and you then consider if those who were convicted can be pardoned. I mean, you should be tried according to the laws in place when you did the (potential) crime, but if society decides that "oops, that law was way too strict", it might make sense to pardon those who were tried and convicted.

text:
My understanding is that the historical basis for these pardons goes back to the time of absolute monarchy.

It was supposed to be a show of Christian mercy for the monarch to go and occasionally pardon people for violating some of their more draconian laws.

text: In the case of an excessive sentence in the US, the sentence is usually commuted. You're still guilty, you just don't have to do the full time. Pardons go a step further and imply forgiveness. The problem with pardons is that you can no longer take the 5th (Amendment), i.e., you are required to testify in court because you have immunity from prosecution related to that crime. That can be a double edged sword. If you refuse to testify, then you are in contempt of court, and an executive pardon does not cover that situation.
